Wimbledon is played in the last week of June and the first week of July, and has been chronologically the third of the four [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] tournaments of the tennis [[Season (sports)|season]] since 1987.<ref name=WProfile/> The event was not held from 1915 to 1918 because of [[World War I]] and again from 1940 to 1945 because of [[World War II]].<ref name=2009aetlcFinals>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[IBM]], [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=Ladies' Singles Finals| url =http://www.wimbledon.org/en_GB/about/history/rolls/ladiesroll.html| accessdate =2010-11-12}}</ref>
The Ladies' Singles' rules have undergone several changes since the first edition. From [[1884 Wimbledon Championships|1884]] until [[1921 Wimbledon Championships|1921]], the event started with a [[Single-elimination tournament|knockout]] phase, the All Comers' Singles, whose winner then faced the defending champion in a [[Glossary of tennis#Challenge Round|challenge round]]. The All Comers' winner was automatically awarded the title six times ([[1887 Wimbledon Championships|1887]], [[1891 Wimbledon Championships|1891]], [[1895 Wimbledon Championships|1895]], [[1907 Wimbledon Championships|1907]], [[1908 Wimbledon Championships|1908]]) in the absence of the previous year's champion. The challenge round system was abolished with the [[1922 Wimbledon Championships|1922]] edition.<ref name=Barrett>{{Cite book | title =100 Wimbledon Championships: A Celebration |isbn=978-0-00218-220-1 |publisher=Collins Willow|first=John|last=Barrett|authorlink =John Barrett (tennis)|year=1986}}</ref> Since the first championships, all matches have been played at the [[Tennis score#Scoring a set|best-of-three sets]]. Between 1884 and [[1883 Wimbledon Championship|1883]], the winner of the next game at five games [[Glossary of tennis#All|â all]] took the set in every match except the All Comers' final, and the challenge round, which were won with six games and a two games advantage. All sets were decided in this [[Glossary of tennis#Advantage format|advantage format]] from [[1884 Wimbledon Championships|1884]] to [[1970 Wimbledon Championships|1970]].<ref name=Barrett/> The [[Glossary of tennis#Lingering death|lingering death]] best-of-12 points [[Tennis score#Scoring a tiebreak game|tie-break]] was introduced in [[1971 Wimbledon Championships|1971]] for the first two sets, played at eight games â all until [[1978 Wimbledon Championships|1978]] and at six games â all since [[1979 Wimbledon Championships|1979]].<ref name=Barrett/><ref name=Tie-break>{{cite web|first=John|last= Roberts |work=[[The Independent]]|title=Tennis: Fast, fan friendly - but full of faults | url =http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/tennis-fast-fan-friendly--but-full-of-faults-1169793.html| date=1998-08-05| accessdate =2009-06-24}}</ref><ref name=SuddenLingering>{{cite web|work=[[The Age]]|publisher=The Age Company Ltd|title=Breaking with tradition| url =http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/01/24/1074732652848.html?from=storyrhs| date=2004-01-25|accessdate =2009-07-27}}</ref>
The Ladies' Singles champion receives a sterling silver salver commonly known as the "[[Venus Rosewater Dish]]", or simply the "Rosewater Dish". The salver, which is 18.75 inches (about 48 cm) in diameter, is decorated with figures from mythology.<ref name=2009aetlcTrophy>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[IBM]], [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=About Wimbledon - History: The trophies| url =http://aeltc2009.wimbledon.org/en_GB/about/history/trophies.html| accessdate =2009-06-24}}</ref> New singles champions are traditionally elected honorary members of the AELTC by the club's committee.{{Ref label|McEnroeMembership|c|c}}<ref name=2009aetlcClub>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[IBM]], [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=About Wimbledon - Behind the scenes: The All England Lawn Tennis Club| url =http://www.wimbledon.org/en_GB/about/guide/club.html| accessdate =2010-11-12}}</ref> In 2011, the Ladies' Singles winner received [[prize money]] of [[Pound sterling|Â£]]1,100,000.<ref name=2009aetlcPrize>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=2011 Prize Money| url =http://aeltc2011.wimbledon.com/content/documents/visiting-wimbledon/2011-prizemoney.pdf|format=PDF| accessdate =2011-07-03}}</ref>
These records include the Amateur Era only, [[Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers]] (1903â1904, 1906, 1910â1911, 1913â1914) holds the record for most titles, with seven, and [[Lottie Dod]] (1891â1893) and [[Suzanne Lenglen]] (1919â1921) holds the record for most consecutive wins in the Ladies' Singles during the challenge round era, with three victories each. The record for most consecutive and most wins post challenge round during the Amateur Era is [[Helen Wills Moody]] (1927â1930), with four straight wins, and Moody holds the record for most victories in this era with eight (1927â1930, 1932â1933, 1935, 1938).<ref name=2009aetlcFinals/>
These records only include the Open Era, since the inclusion of the professional tennis players, [[Martina Navratilova]] (1978â1979, 1982â1987, 1990) holds the record for most victories with nine. Navratilova holds the record for most consecutive victories with six (1982â1987).<ref name=2009aetlcFinals/>
This event has been won without the loss of a set, during the Open Era of Tennis, by the following players: [[Chris Evert]] in 1981, Martina Navratilova in 1983, 1984, 1986, and 1990, [[Lindsay Davenport]] in 1999, [[Serena Williams]] in 2002 and 2010 and [[Venus Williams]] in 2008.

==Notes== {{Refbegin}} *{{note label|Indoor|a|a}} Since 2009, [[Centre Court]] features a [[retractable roof]], allowing [[Tennis court#Indoor courts|indoor]] and night-time play.<ref name=Indoor>{{cite web|first=Neil|last= Harman|work=[[The Times]]|publisher=[[News International|Times Newspapers Ltd]]|title=No more soaked strawberries - Centre Court, Wimbledon, gets a roof| url =http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/tennis/article6143439.ece| date=2009-04-22|accessdate =2009-07-19}}</ref> *{{note label|OpenEra|b|b}} Wimbledon entered the [[History of tennis#Open Era|Open Era]] with the [[1968 Wimbledon Championships|1968]] edition, allowing [[professional]] players to compete alongside [[amateur]]s.<ref name=2009aetlcHistory/> *{{note label|McEnroeMembership|c|c}} [[John McEnroe]] is the only player to have been denied membership in [[1981 Wimbledon Championships|1981]], because of his on-court behaviour during the championships.<ref name=McEnroeMembership1>{{cite web|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|publisher=[[United Press International]]|title=Jolly snub for McEnroe; he's refused All-England| url =http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19810710&id=HvcNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F3sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4541,1270028| date=1981-07-10|accessdate =2009-07-27}}</ref><ref name=McEnroeMembership2>{{cite web|first=Avi|last=Zenilman|work=[[The New Yorker]]|publisher=[[CondÃ© Nast Publications]]|title=Back Issues: McEnroe vs. Thatcher| url =http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2009/06/back-issues-john-mcenroe-vs-margaret-thatcher.html| date=2009-06-24|accessdate =2009-07-27}}</ref> *{{note label|Year|d|d}} Each year is linked to an article about that particular years draws, but pre-1922 they did not have draws due to the challenge round system. In 1922 till the present they do have draws, but the years of 1925–1939 do not have draw pages made to link to, so it is linked to the year(s) articles instead. *{{note label|BRI|e|e}} "British Isles" (BRI) is used for players from the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] (1801–1922), distinct from "Great Britain" (GBR) used for players from the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland]] (1922–present).<ref name=2009aetlcFinals/><ref name=2009aetlcCountries>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[IBM]], [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=History - Rolls of Honour: Country abbreviations| url =http://aeltc2009.wimbledon.org/en_GB/about/history/rolls/CountryAbbreviations.html| accessdate =2009-07-17}}</ref> *{{note label|WWI|f|f}} The tournament was not held from 1915 to 1918 because of World War I.<ref name=2009aetlcFinals/> *{{note label|WWII|g|g}} The tournament was not held from 1940 to 1945 because of World War II.<ref name=2009aetlcFinals/> *{{note label|TCH|h|h}} [[Czechoslovakia]] (TCH, 1918–1992) split into the [[Czech Republic]] (CZE, 1992–present) and [[Slovakia]] (SVK, 1992–present). *{{note label|NAVUSA|i|i}} [[Martina Navratilova]] was born in Czechoslovakia, but she competed as an American because she sought asylum in the United States, which made her have to relinquish her Czechoslovakian citizenship, so after the US Open in 1975 she competed as an American.{{Citation needed| date=August 2011}} *{{note label|FRGGER|j|j}} FRG is West Germany, but after unification became just Germany (GER) after 1990. {{Refend}}
